array.string: CD4 (T4 helper) cells are immune cells. The count is measured per unit (mm3) of blood and indicates the health of the immune system. The normal range is between 500 - 1500.

The ratio between 2 different immune cells, T4 (helper CD4) and T8(killer CD8) cells. The ratio is given in %. The CD4% value indicates the health of the immune system. CD4% tends to fluctuate less than CD4 count . The normal range is between 20-40%.
The amount of HIV virus in blood (measured as per unit blood mm3).

Undetectable refers to a very low count of HIV virus in blood. The threshold for 'undetectable' depends on the Viral Load test and may range from 50 to ca 200. Undetectable does not mean the virus has left the body.
Current guidelines recommend the start of treatment when the CD4 count is persistently at or below 350.

A whole range of different drug types are available and new ones are developed all the time. The 5 main types are: protease inhibitors, NRTI (nukes), NNRTI (non-nukes), fusion/entry inhibitors and integrase inhibitors. Often patients are prescribed drugs that combine more than 1 type (e.g. Atripla).

When HIV infects a cell it "reprogrammes" the cell to produce new virus copies. This typically leads to the death of the infected cell. HIV drugs prevent the virus from multiplying within the infected cell.
What is Adherence? And why is it important that I take my drugs regularly?

Anti HIV medication needs to be taken regularly - typically within +/- 1 hour of the specified time. Sticking to the drug regime is called 'adherence'. It is important to avoid the virus from becoming resistant to the medication.
